YouTube tends to transcribe “ChatGPT” as “Chachi BT”. Funny.

items.content_html:
I just finished watching Modern Family.

For about five years, it’s been a constant part of our routine when my wife and I have lunch together at home. The last time we watched the show, Season 11‚Äîthe final season‚Äîwasn’t available in France, so we rewatched the entire series. Now, we’ve finally completed Season 11. It was an emotional moment, both on screen and in our living room.

I’m not sure why it’s not more popular among our friends, but for me, it’s definitely in my hall of fame. üçø

items.content_html:
I just finished watching Bad Monkey on Apple TV+. It was really good and I highly recommend it.

Some notes:

  • The showrunner, Bill Lawrence, who was also behind Ted Lasso and Shrinking delivered again. The Ringer has a piece about him;
  • Eve Stripling is easily one of the most compelling villains I’ve seen in a while;
  • The soundtrack is spot-on and adds so much to the vibe;
  • The “good guys” are all super charming and relatable;
  • It’s based on a novel by Carl Hiaasen, and it feels like it shares the same DNA as the works of Laurent Chalumeau ‚Äî both clearly influenced by the legendary Elmore Leonard.

üçø

Big thanks to Manton Reece for pointing me to this hilarious bit by John Mulaney about captchas.

It‚Äôs now up there with Michael McIntyre’s sketch on passwords in the hall of fame of tech-related comedy. üíª √ó üçø

items.content_html:
Naming things is quite famously one of the hardest problems in software development.

When you realize there is a better name for something, it’s important to rename it, even if it’s tricky. Clear, accurate names improve the developer experience, while bad names make maintenance harder, slower, and riskier. Leaving sub-optimal names in a codebase is technical debt. üíª

items.title: A simple workflow for translation keys typed with TypeScript
items.content_html:
Since my web projects use typed translation keys, my work in progress would typically add unwanted TypeScript errors every time I added a new translation key, and that would annoy me a lot.

So I wrote a little script that watches a temporary JSON translation file (as used by Lokalise) and merges it into all the translation files of the languages that are supported every time it changes.

This way, once I am done with a feature, I can upload the new keys all at once in Lokalise’s upload tool. üíª

items.title: Apple Event 2024: Carbon Footprint of the iPhone 16 Series
items.content_html:
I recently watched the 2024 Apple Event, where they briefly discussed their efforts toward carbon neutrality by 2030. While the event touched on Apple’s sustainable packaging initiatives, their website provides more detailed information on the environmental impact of their products.

Here‚Äôs what I found about the carbon footprint of the latest iPhones:

  • The iPhone 16 Pro Max 256 Go has a carbon footprint of 74 kg.
  • The iPhone 16 Plus 128 Go has a carbon footprint of 60 kg.

Quite better than the Apple Vision Pro.

If you’re interested in learning more about Apple’s progress toward sustainability and carbon neutrality, their website offers comprehensive details. It’s worth considering how these efforts align with their 2030 environmental goals.

üíª

items.title: How to Remove YouTube Controls from a Paused Video for Better Screenshots
items.content_html:
If you’ve ever tried to take a clean screenshot from a paused YouTube video, you’ve probably noticed the overlay controls and gradient at the bottom of the screen that get in the way. Fortunately, there’s a simple solution using JavaScript in the browser console:

The steps to remove YouTube controls are:

  1. Pause the video at the frame you want to capture.
  2. Open the browser console (typically by pressing F12 or Ctrl + Shift + I).
  3. Run the following JavaScript code to remove the bottom gradient and control bar:
document.querySelector(".ytp-gradient-bottom").remove()
document.querySelector(".ytp-chrome-bottom").remove()

After running this, the video controls and gradient will disappear, allowing you to take a clean screenshot of the paused video.

üíª
items.content_text:
If you've ever tried to take a clean screenshot from a paused YouTube video, you've probably noticed the overlay controls and gradient at the bottom of the screen that get in the way. Fortunately, there's a simple solution using JavaScript in the browser console:

The steps to remove YouTube controls are:

1. **Pause the video** at the frame you want to capture.
2. **Open the browser console** (typically by pressing `F12` or `Ctrl + Shift + I`).
3. **Run the following JavaScript code** to remove the bottom gradient and control bar:


```js
document.querySelector(".ytp-gradient-bottom").remove()
document.querySelector(".ytp-chrome-bottom").remove()
```

After running this, the video controls and gradient will disappear, allowing you to take a clean screenshot of the paused video.

üíª

items.content_html:
On the UK willing to be a clean energy superpower

Thank you Keir Starmer.

It takes courage for governments to advance their climate change agenda because it impacts people both economically‚Äîlikely destroying some jobs in the short term‚Äîand personally, as changing habits is a difficult process.

In a slightly longer term, by 2050, for example, failing to make progress will hurt people significantly more.

It is reassuring that in the UK, climate change is a concern across a large section of the political spectrum. It is not surprising that parties genuinely caring for most people have bolder objectives.

It is also not surprising that far-right leaders do not care. They prioritize power over people. The only traits I can think of that would lead someone to deny the need for climate action are selfishness, cowardice and ignorance. Not the best traits.

üèõÔ∏è

items.content_html:
This interview with Lori Gottlieb by Jon Stewart helps me realize my political anxiety is normal and that I should try to make it productive. But what can I do?

  • Get involved in a campaign? Writing my thoughts is as far as I can go. Whenever I tried joining a political group, its internal politics and strategics were repulsive to me.
  • Volunteer? I just found a program to help kids with homework, via jeveuxaider.gouv.fr that I didn’t know about.
  • Vote? ‚úÖ
  • Encourage people around you to vote? ‚úÖ

It still feels like not enough.

Also, Jon is hilarious:

My anxiety has never saved me from bears, but it often convinces me I’m not lovable.

üèõÔ∏è
items.content_text:
[This interview with Lori Gottlieb by Jon Stewart](https://youtu.be/Vb6YSYaQPJg) helps me realize my political anxiety is _normal_ and that I should try to make it _productive_. But what can I do?

* Get involved in a campaign? Writing [my thoughts](https://www.deadrooster.org/notes-post-dissolution/) is as far as I can go. Whenever I tried joining a political group, its internal politics and strategics were repulsive to me.
* Volunteer? I just found a program to help kids with homework, via [jeveuxaider.gouv.fr](https://www.jeveuxaider.gouv.fr/) that I didn't know about. 
* Vote? ‚úÖ
* Encourage people around you to vote? ‚úÖ

It still feels like not enough.

Also, Jon is hilarious:

> My anxiety has never saved me from bears, but it often convinces me I'm not lovable.

üèõÔ∏è

items.title: Thoughts about the state of web tooling
items.content_html:
I spent some time yesterday evening with a starter template of Remix + Vite. Here are a few thoughts:

  • I couldn’t figure out how to import CSS. The Remix documentation referred to Vite’s, which was technology-agnostic and suggested that importing CSS should be straightforward. However, my attempts failed. When simple tasks become difficult, I understand the strange popularity of Tailwind.
  • Vercel has its own package to run Remix, leading Remix to remove their Vercel starter template from their repository. From an outside perspective, it seems ego battles are harming the developer experience.
  • Sass seems to be considered outdated compared to all the PostCSS options.

I still believe the web is moving towards some consolidation among tools, but it’s very frustrating right now. üíª

items.title: Asteroid City, 2023 - ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
Wes Anderson‚Äôs ‚ÄúAsteroid City‚Äù‚Äôs rhythm is frenetic, and it's hard to find time to breathe. I had heard that it was a bit over the top, even for Wes Anderson fans, and it is indeed true. However, the lighting is spectacular, and I think the images will stay forever in the minds of those who see it.

The film addresses loneliness, being an outcast, and how different scales of life impact each other: from personal to communal, national, or even cosmic levels. Individuals have little control over threats like nuclear war, quarantines, or UFO interventions, or even over how to grieve, both individually and collectively. It emphasizes that everyone has a role to play at every level, encapsulated in the final mantra, "You can't wake up if you don't fall asleep." This suggests that being perpetually active and busy might prevent us from seeing the bigger picture of our intentions with our lives or the impact we can have on challenging the absurdities of our Western governments.

Wes Anderson's usual magic lies in his movies being so rich in details that they offer a new experience with each viewing. They create a framework where your attention can explore different details each time. "Asteroid City" seems to be no exception, and I look forward to watching it again.

items.content_html:
Il y a quelques semaines, je parlais de la VAR. Cette semaine, la Premier League a aussi fait le point en insistant sur le fait que, selon elle, la VAR fonctionne puisque le taux de mauvaises d√©cisions arbitrales est pass√© de 18% √† 4%, en conc√©dant qu’il fallait am√©liorer la fan experience.

Point par point :

  • Trop lent. L’id√©e ici est d’utiliser un syst√®me semi-automatique de d√©tection des hors-jeu. OK, attendons de voir.
  • Trop opaque. Ouvrir le micro des arbitres est souhait√© par la Premier League, mais emp√™ch√© par les lois du football √©tablies par l’IFAB. Donc, cr√©er des cartons bleus c’est envisageable, mais donner une voix aux arbitres, c’est non. Sans avoir la raison du pourquoi, c’est une posture qui me semble compliqu√©e √† d√©fendre.
  • Trop arbitraire. L√† dessus, l’IFAB est intransigeante : ‚Äù√âtant donn√© que chaque d√©cision/incident sera v√©rifi√©, les entra√Æneurs ou les joueurs n’ont pas √† demander une v√©rification ou une analyse.‚Äù L√†, √ßa commence √† se mordre la queue entre exhaustivit√© des v√©rifications, opacit√© et lenteur.

Bref, √ßa bosse, mais faut faire vite, car y’en a qui ont mis le pied dans la porte.

#238 ‚öΩÔ∏è
items.content_text:
Il y a quelques semaines, [je parlais de la VAR](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-233). Cette semaine, [la Premier League a aussi fait le point](https://theathletic.com/5258531/2024/02/07/premier-league-var-briefing/) en insistant sur le fait que, selon elle, la VAR fonctionne puisque le taux de mauvaises d√©cisions arbitrales est pass√© de 18% √† 4%, en conc√©dant qu'il fallait am√©liorer la _fan experience_.

Point par point :
* **Trop lent.** L'id√©e ici est d'utiliser un syst√®me semi-automatique de d√©tection des hors-jeu. OK, attendons de voir.
* **Trop opaque.** Ouvrir le micro des arbitres est souhait√© par la Premier League, mais emp√™ch√© par les lois du football √©tablies par l'IFAB. Donc, cr√©er [des cartons bleus](https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Un-nouveau-carton-avec-suspension-temporaire-va-etre-teste/1447595) c'est envisageable, mais donner une voix aux arbitres, c'est non. Sans avoir la raison du pourquoi, c'est une posture qui me semble compliqu√©e √† d√©fendre. 
* **Trop arbitraire.** L√† dessus, l'IFAB est [intransigeante](https://www.theifab.com/fr/laws/latest/video-assistant-referee-var-protocol/#procedures) : ‚Äù√âtant donn√© que chaque d√©cision/incident sera v√©rifi√©, les entra√Æneurs ou les joueurs n'ont pas √† demander une v√©rification ou une analyse.‚Äù L√†, √ßa commence √† se mordre la queue entre exhaustivit√© des v√©rifications, opacit√© et lenteur.

Bref, √ßa bosse, mais faut faire vite, car y'en a qui ont mis [le pied dans la porte](https://www.sofoot.com/breves/lenorme-somme-que-la-superligue-reclamerait-a-luefa). 

[#238](https://www.statium.app/newsletter/posts/newsletter-238) ‚öΩÔ∏è

items.title: How much the Apple Vision Pro costs‚Ä¶ environmentally
items.content_html:
The carbon footprint of an Apple Vision Pro amounts to 335kg of greenhouse gas emissions, slightly higher than the 300kg emitted by the 16-inch MacBook Pro I currently use. This represents approximately 15% of a yearly emissions budget of 2 tons, or about 3% when depreciated over a 5-year period.

As a programmer specializing in Apple technologies, I am naturally curious about the Apple Vision Pro. However, I have decided against purchasing one, not primarily due to financial constraints, but because I believe its environmental impact exceeds what is justifiable for a product that remains largely nonessential.

For numerous reasons, I hope the Apple Vision Pro fails to gain traction. However, it seems unlikely. Therefore, I urge you to consider its environmental cost as seriously as its monetary expense before making a purchasing decision. Please aim to offset emissions elsewhere, just as you would seek to save money in other areas if you choose to acquire one.

üíª


items.content_html: Jekyll still has a pulse. Should I reconsider moving on? Probably not. Since Ruby is not as needed for iOS development as it used to (CocoaPods being replaced by SPM, fastlane being replaced by Xcode Cloud), it became my 3rd language. Soon to be 4th if I hold on to my resolution to learn Rust this year. I also found out about Astro, which is a good mix between Jekyll and going full on Remix. üíª
items.content_text: Jekyll still has [a pulse](https://jekyllrb.com/news/2023/12/27/jekyll-4-3-3-released/). Soon to be 4th if I hold on to my resolution to learn Rust this year. I also found out about [Astro](https://astro.build/), which is a good mix between Jekyll and going full on Remix. üíª

J’ai regard√© une masterclass de Kevin de Bruyne publi√©e par Manchester City o√π le milieu belge partage sa science de la passe. Je la recommande, mais un passage m’a fait grincer des dents, o√π le bon Kevin glisse un petit taquet √† ce qu’on appelle les data :

Pass completion is a word that I don’t care about and I will never care about.

En gros, les taux de r√©ussite de passe, il s’en fiche, et il s’en fichera toujours. Certes, Kevin de Bruyne est seulement dans le 7√®me percentile en taux de r√©ussite de passe donc peut-√™tre que ses coachs lui rabattent les oreilles avec √ßa. Cependant, il peut s’en fiche seulement parce qu’il est exceptionnel dans les autres cat√©gories statistiques de passe.

C’est comme un millionnaire qui dirait qu’il s’en fiche de tenir un budget.

Pour √™tre honn√™te, Kevin nuance un peu la chose ensuite, mais c’est cet extrait qui a √©t√© retenu lors du montage comme extrait de d√©but de vid√©o pour attirer le chaland (√ßa a un nom cette technique ?). Bref, coup de gueule contre les critiques √† l’emporte-pi√®ce contre les data du foot.

items.content_html: I love open-source code, but when I come across something that needs improvement in an open-source repository, I sometimes hesitate to point it out because I don’t want to be seen as overly critical or ungrateful. However, I recently felt it was the right thing to do when I raised the issue that vapor-community/bcrypt may no longer be relevant in a somewhat positive manner. Most importantly, I want to express my gratitude to @0xTim@hachyderm.io for their time and dedication to the Swift Server Workgroup. üíª
items.content_text: I love open-source code, but when I come across something that needs improvement in an open-source repository, I sometimes hesitate to point it out because I don't want to be seen as overly critical or ungrateful. items.content_html: Bandcamp Schadenfreude. I was offered a deal to become an employee for Bandcamp back in 2011. Then the deal was off for reasons that didn’t make sense. Since then, I had mixed feelings: I liked the product as a listener, not so much as a musician, and I resent founders and managers from then ‚Äî I know I shouldn’t but I do ‚Äî and I am not sure they are genuinely nice people. üíª
items.content_text: [Bandcamp Schadenfreude](https://pxlnv.com/linklog/worrying-about-bandcamp/). I was offered a deal to become an employee for Bandcamp back in 2011. Then the deal was off for reasons that didn't make sense. Since then, I had mixed feelings: I liked the product as a listener, not so much [as a musician](https://thelivingstonesipresume.bandcamp.com/), and I resent founders and managers from then ‚Äî [I know I shouldn't](https://dailystoic.com/you-cant-resent-them/) but I do ‚Äî and I am not sure they are genuinely nice people. üíª

items.title: Writing on the web post-Jekyll, Ghost edition
items.content_html:
Jekyll does not seem to do well. Despite being used by GitHub for GitHub pages, largely used plugins from the community ‚Äî such as jekyll-assets, ‚Äî are falling behind Jekyll 4 or the end of life of Ruby 2.

Ghost has very convincing pros: it is easy, fast and beautiful. It also has everything one can need fully integrated when you just start publishing.

But for a technical person such like me, who has an history of web publishing behind, it also has major cons:

  • MySQL over PostgreSQL. I already run a PostgreSQL DB. I don’t want to run another one;
  • All the built-ins (SEO, analytics) are lost when Ghost is used as a headless CMS;
  • Poor markdown support: line breaks are preserved in posts;
  • Lack of control over the HTML that is being produced;
  • No support of multiple websites for small publishers.

As such, Ghost does not sound like a good CMS solution for me. To be continued. üíª

items.content_html:
üé∏ I fell in some intense Interpol nostalgia these last weeks. And i learnt how to play Say Hello to the Angels on the guitar. I also tried to understand how “it works” in terms of music theory.

Most of the guitar resources online lack interactivity and visual cues (even videos, which mostly show narrators speaking).

I wonder if there is an unexplored way to write nice interactive blog posts about learning how songs are constructed.

items.content_html: üë®‚Äçüíª Yesterday, I pulled out my Sortmash iOS app code off dusty shelves as I needed to sort a large amount of data by order of preference ‚Äî namely my Sorare cards ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Äî and it was a very fun experience. Exploring a pre-ARC Objective-C with embedded dependencies ‚Äî TouchJSON and ASIHTTPRequest ‚Äî felt like traveling in time, and made me so grateful of where we stand now. Making the code run again was surprisingly easy but visually very buggy since the code was from an era where iPhone and iPad had each a unique screen size.
